author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Oxford’s 2023 Word of the Year Is … ‘Rizz’
description: Sorry, Swifties. The Gen Z slang term — derived from “charisma” — went viral this year after the actor Tom Holland claimed to have none.
content: It’s official. Oxford University Press, the world’s second-oldest academic press and the publisher of the Oxford English Dictionary, has rizz.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘There Was Only One Small Table That We Didn’t End Up Using’
description: Dining out after a City Hall wedding, a walk in Carnegie Hill and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: Munich Airport Resumes Operations After Major Snowfall
description: Heavy snow in Southern Germany on Saturday prompted authorities to shut the airport and rail station. Service at both remained limited on Sunday.
content: The airport in Munich resumed limited operations Sunday morning after being closed for nearly a day because of record snowfall that disrupted transportation across the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Maduro, Under Pressure, Holds Vote to Annex Territory From a Neighbor
description: The Venezuelan president is holding a referendum to claim sovereignty over Essequibo, a large oil-rich area of neighboring Guyana.
content: Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, finds himself in a political bind. He is under pressure from the United States to hold free and fair elections after years of authoritarian rule or face a reinstatement of crippling economic sanctions. But analysts say he is unlikely to give up power and would most likely lose in a credible election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 4, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Fate of Billions for Opioid Victims From Sacklers Rests With Supreme Court
description: The court will decide whether Purdue’s owners can gain permanent immunity from future opioid lawsuits in exchange for payments up to $6 billion.
content: In 2014, when the first opioid lawsuits were filed against Purdue Pharma, Tiffinee Scott’s daughter was still years away from her fatal overdose from addictive prescription painkillers, including Purdue’s OxyContin, which she was taking to manage sickle cell pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: Why Anonymous Sperm Donation Is Over, and Why That Matters
description: Activists are trying to end secrecy for sperm and egg donors — a campaign that troubles some L.G.B.T.Q. families.
content: A few years ago, when he was in his early 30s, Tyler Levy Sniff took a home DNA test he received as a gift. The results revealed a staggering truth: His father wasn’t biologically related to him. Levy Sniff confronted his parents, who explained that after years of trying and failing to have a baby, they turned to a sperm donor. Following the standard advice at the time, they decided not to tell him for fear of driving a wedge into their family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Why More Chinese Are Risking Danger in Southern Border Crossings to U.S.
description: Trekking the perilous Darién Gap and seeking asylum are risks worth taking for migrants from China who have lost hope in the country’s future.
content: Gao Zhibin and his daughter left Beijing on Feb. 24 for a better life, a safer one. Over the next 35 days, by airplane, train, boat, bus and foot, they traveled through nine countries. By the time they touched American soil in late March, Mr. Gao had lost 30 pounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: 2 Years After Its Default, China Evergrande May Finally Meet Its End
description: A Hong Kong judge could set in motion the liquidation of the property developer, which was once considered one of China’s most successful companies.
content: Once China’s most prolific property developer, China Evergrande may soon be its biggest and messiest corporate breakup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu, Raúl Vilchis and Photographs By Todd Heisler
title: Venezuelan Migrants Could Soon Create New York’s First ‘Little Caracas’
description: Venezuelan flags, foods and accents are spreading along a stretch of Roosevelt Avenue in Queens as thousands of newly arrived migrants make their home in the city.
content: Under an elevated subway track in Queens, Victor José Hernandez was whipping up the pepitos that he had perfected at a street cart in Caracas, Venezuela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: This Chicken Should Be in Every Pot
description: Warm spices, sweet root vegetables, savory chicken — a perfect dinner.
content: Good morning. I can see the scene in my head: yellow leaves skittering down the sidewalk, gathering in piles at the base of stoops as the late-afternoon sun begins its drop. It’s cold, getting colder, and we’re hustling along with a few bottles of wine, a baguette and a bag of slick and salty Marcona almonds to share.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Says Goodbye to George Santos
description: “S.N.L.” and Bowen Yang took a parting jab at Santos the day after he was expelled from Congress. Emma Stone was the host.
content: Christmas won’t arrive for three more weeks but “Saturday Night Live” got an early present: When Congress voted on Friday to expel Representative George Santos, it was a bow-tied comedy gift that “S.N.L.” wasted no time unwrapping in this weekend’s broadcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Team’s Sale Reflects Growing Links Between Pro Sports and Gambling
description: The proposed purchase of the N.B.A.’s Dallas Mavericks by a casino operator is the latest sign of how fully leagues have embraced the gaming world.
content: For years, professional sports organizations like the National Basketball Association and Major League Baseball prohibited liquor companies from buying advertising in locations in stadiums and arenas that could be seen on television, in deference to efforts to curb drunken driving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Ivan Penn
title: Alaska Airlines Plans to Buy Hawaiian Airlines
description: The deal, valued at $1.9 billion, would further consolidate the airline industry and is likely to face close scrutiny by federal antitrust regulators.
content: Alaska Airlines said on Sunday that it planned to buy Hawaiian Airlines for $1.9 billion, a deal that would further consolidate the airline industry and probably attract the scrutiny of federal regulators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Hard Truths About Suffering, From a Writer Who’s Lived to Tell
description: In “Zero at the Bone,” Christian Wiman offers a welcome tonic: poetic and philosophical reminders of how to get through troubling times.
content: “One grows so tired, in American public life,” Christian Wiman writes with sudden invigoration, “of the certitudes and platitudes, the megaphone mouths and stadium praise, influencers and effluencers and the whole tsunami of slop that comes pouring into our lives like toxic sludge.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Paris Attack Suspect Pledged Allegiance to ISIS, Prosecutor Says
description: The man, identified as Armand Rajabpour-Miyandoab, was known to French intelligence services for Islamist extremism and psychiatric disorders.
content: The main suspect in an assault that left one tourist dead and two other people injured in Paris was known to French intelligence services for Islamist extremism and had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State before the attack, the French authorities said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: The Year’s Best Movies
description: See what our critics picked.
content: I found myself at the movies this year more often than last. The data suggests that I’m not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oona A. Hathaway
title: I Clerked for Justice O’Connor. She Was My Hero, but I Worry About Her Legacy.
description: She stands as a shining example of how women — everyone, really — can approach life and work.
content: When I learned that Justice Sandra Day O’Connor had died, I felt not just the loss of a world historical figure but also the loss of someone who formed a part of my identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: In Florida’s Hot Political Climate, Some Faculty Have Had Enough
description: Liberal-leaning professors are leaving coveted jobs with tenure. And there are signs that recruiting scholars has become harder.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis had just taken office in 2019 when the University of Florida lured Neil H. Buchanan, a prominent economist and tax law scholar, from George Washington University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: What Happened With Fortnite’s Eminem Concert This Weekend?
description: Some fans were left frustrated after a much-hyped event failed to handle the digital crowds.
content: Isobel Bushell, 19, knew Fortnite’s Big Bang event was going to be popular. The live event, hosted Saturday by Epic Games, promised to introduce new experiences for the beloved battle video game and to feature a musical performance by the rapper Eminem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Emma Bubola
title: 5 Dead, Including Suspect, and 2 Officers Wounded in Queens Stabbing
description: The attack occurred early Sunday morning at a house in Far Rockaway, where the suspect also started a fire, the police said.
content: It was still dark on Sunday morning when a man who the authorities said had just killed four family members at their Queens home set the house on fire and slipped out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Dr Pepper Awards Two $100,000 Scholarships to Correct Halftime Blunder
description: Dr Pepper awarded each of the contestants in the college football halftime challenge the grand prize after a review found a counting error.
content: The Big 12 Championship game between the Texas Longhorns and the Oklahoma State Cowboys on Saturday delivered the kind of controversy-mired barn burner that inspires legions of college football fans to pack stadiums and jam sports bars every weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Deadly Paris Knife Attack Revives Terrorism Concerns
description: The authorities said the suspect had serious psychiatric disorders and told the police he was upset over the deaths of Muslims around the world, including in Gaza.
content: A German tourist was killed and several other people were injured in central Paris late Saturday after a man attacked them with a knife and a hammer, the French authorities said. The case stirred fears of renewed Islamist terrorist attacks in a nation already on edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: With Big State Victories, Modi Expands His Dominance in India
description: Results of voting for the governments of four Indian states showed gains for Mr. Modi’s ruling party, putting him in a strong position ahead of general elections in the spring.
content: The ruling party of Prime Minister Narendra Modi has tightened its grip over India’s populous northern belt, results of state elections showed Sunday, expanding its dominance of a key region ahead of general elections in which Mr. Modi is seeking a third term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Why Doctors and Pharmacists Are in Revolt
description: Once accustomed to a status outside the usual management-labor hierarchy, many health professionals now feel as put upon as any clock-punching worker.
content: Dr. John Wust does not come off as a labor agitator. A longtime obstetrician-gynecologist from Louisiana with a penchant for bow ties, Dr. Wust spent the first 15 years of his career as a partner in a small business — that is, running his own practice with colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: 10 Performances That Pushed Emotional Limits
description: For our critic-at-large, the year was marked by the Black excellence of “Purlie Victorious,” the brutality of “Bottoms” and rage of “Beef.”
content: For me, 2023 was a year of entertainment that captured people pushed to their emotional limits, whether that was the rage of two bitter enemies, the desperation of a widow who only sees a future of annihilation or the pent-up aggression of a bunch of high school girls. But it was also a year of colorful, funny and biting Black stories on stages. Throw in a dancing goth, a freshly single New York City fashionista and a chronicle of a dying band, and you’ve got my top picks for everything that tickled my fancy in the past year across theater, film and TV.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 3, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Dec. 3, 2023.
content: An article last weekend in which a writer details his experience arriving in New York City as one of 140,000 Jewish refugees who fled postwar Europe misstated the number of days that asylum seekers must wait before applying for a work permit. It is 150 days, not 180, though a permit will not be granted before 180 days after an asylum seeker has arrived. The article also misidentified the U.S.S. General A.W. Greely. It was a Navy vessel when the author and his family arrived in New York City on March 3, 1950, not a merchant marine vessel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Michael Levenson
title: Siblings Fight Over Estate of Mother Whose Land Yielded a T. Rex Skeleton
description: The skeleton, which was found on a ranch in South Dakota in 1990 and later sold for more than $8 million, has been the subject of numerous legal challenges.
content: Darlene Williams died in 2020, more than a dozen years after the $8 million sale of a fossilized skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex named Sue that was found on her family’s ranch in South Dakota in 1990.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump’s Defense to Charge That He’s Anti-Democratic? Accuse Biden of It
description: Indicted over a plot to overturn an election and campaigning on promises to shatter democratic norms in a second term, Donald Trump wants voters to see Joe Biden as the bigger threat.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has been indicted by federal prosecutors for conspiracy to defraud the United States in connection with a plot to overturn the 2020 election, repeatedly claimed to supporters in Iowa on Saturday that it was President Biden who posed a severe threat to American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: It’s Time to Fix America’s Most Dangerous Law
description: The Insurrection Act is deeply flawed, and the possibility of a second Trump presidency makes its defects terrifyingly clear.
content: There is a land mine embedded in the United States Code, one that Donald Trump, if re-elected president, could use to destroy our republic. But it’s not too late for Congress to defuse the mine now and protect America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: ‘Medical Freedom’ Activists Take Aim at New Target: Childhood Vaccine Mandates
description: Mississippi has long had high childhood immunization rates, but a federal judge has ordered the state to allow parents to opt out on religious grounds.
content: For more than 40 years, Mississippi had one of the strictest school vaccination requirements in the nation, and its high childhood immunization rates have been a source of pride. But in July, the state began excusing children from vaccination if their parents cited religious objections, after a federal judge sided with a “medical freedom” group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Who’s Who Behind the Dawn of the Modern Artificial Intelligence Movement
description: Before chatbots exploded in popularity, a group of researchers, tech executives and venture capitalists had worked for more than a decade to fuel A.I.
content: While artificial intelligence has taken the limelight over the past year, technology that can appear to operate like human brains has been top of mind for researchers, investors and tech executives in Silicon Valley and beyond for more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Historic Stretch
description: Sean Ziebarth lets us start from scratch.
content: Jump to Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: DeSantis Says He Would Pass a Bill to ‘Supersede’ Obamacare
description: The comments from Florida’s governor on Sunday followed a similar statement by former President Donald J. Trump; Democrats have denounced their stances.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said on Sunday that, if elected president, he would pursue legislation that would “supersede” the Affordable Care Act, echoing former President Donald J. Trump’s comments, which Democrats seized upon last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek Guy
title: Frasier Still Wants to Look Rich. Does He?
description: A popular sitcom from the ’90s has returned with an updated wardrobe that reflects shifts in American elitism.
content: Nearly two decades after its original run, the beloved American sitcom “Frasier” has been resurrected by Paramount+, and the actor Kelsey Grammer slipped right back into character with all the charm that endeared him to audiences throughout the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Navy Destroyer Shoots Down Three Drones in Red Sea, Pentagon Says
description: A Pentagon official said the U.S.S. Carney shot down the drones as several commercial ships nearby came under fire on Sunday, in attacks that U.S. Central Command said came from Iran-backed Yemeni Houthis.
content: A U.S. Navy destroyer shot down three drones during a sustained attack in the Red Sea on Sunday, the Pentagon said, in what could signal another escalation in the tit-for-tat attacks between the American military and Iranian-backed militants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Mooallem
title: Michael Stipe Is Writing His Next Act. Slowly.
description: How do you reinvent yourself after being a global superstar? The former R.E.M. frontman is still figuring that out.
content: When Michael Stipe was little, his parents called him Mr. Mouse. He was a scurrier. As soon as he could stand, he ran, and when he ran, he ran until he face-planted. His mother would deposit him in a baby walker, but if Stipe scrambled as fast as he could and hit the threshold of a doorway with a running start, he could topple the walker and eject himself onto the floor. Then he’d spring to his feet and run away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Karen Weise, Nico Grant and Mike Isaac
title: Ego, Fear and Money: How the A.I. Fuse Was Lit
description: The people who were most afraid of the risks of artificial intelligence decided they should be the ones to build it. Then distrust fueled a spiraling competition.
content: Elon Musk celebrated his 44th birthday in July 2015 at a three-day party thrown by his wife at a California wine country resort dotted with cabins. It was family and friends only, with children racing around the upscale property in Napa Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Ukrainians in Germany Weigh Wrenching Choice: Stay or Go Home
description: As refugees, they were welcomed with safety, services and jobs. As the war grinds on, giving that up is not a simple decision.
content: Since fleeing Ukraine with her daughter, Iryna Khomich has made a home of a tiny space in a village of prefabricated units in southwestern Germany. A full tour of its single room takes only a few moments: an iron bunk bed and a wardrobe, shoes scattered near the door, clothes drying on radiators. On one recent afternoon, her cat, Dimka, walked in and out, while her daughter, Sofiia, 8, read a German textbook at a desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Paul Lynch Feared His Novel Would End His Career. It Won the Booker.
description: “Prophet Song” has earned comparisons to dystopian classics like “1984.” But Lynch downplays the book’s political message. This book, he says, was deeply personal.
content: When Paul Lynch started writing his novel “Prophet Song,” he worried it might destroy his career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: DeSantis Finishes His Iowa 99, Hoping for a Bump Against Trump
description: The Florida governor said his tour of all the state’s counties was evidence of his commitment to Iowa voters, even as he remained far behind Donald Trump in state polls.
content: Ron DeSantis took the stage in Jasper County in Iowa on Saturday, heralding his appearance as the culmination of his tour of the state’s 99 counties, and hoping to inject enthusiasm into his well-funded but struggling presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: Where Avocados Grow and the People Speak Carefully
description: Times reporters on assignment in Michoacán, Mexico, found a drastically altered landscape and dangers to those who protest deforestation.
content: In October, the Times journalists Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega were in the Mexican state of Michoacán, traveling across volcanic plateaus that are known for their towering pine and oak forests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: The Best Romances of 2023
description: Here are the novels our columnist loved most.
content: A best books list is one of my favorite rituals. As the calendar flutters to its final pages, we glance fondly back over the highest peaks climbed in 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What Motivates the Motivators?
description: The life of a fitness instructor involves 4 a.m. starts, too much coffee, exercising for work, exercising for fun, and working in some “me” time.
content: For many people, a physically demanding exercise class can be an outlet to relieve the stress of a busy workweek. But what happens when that exercise class is your workweek?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Books That Explain Where We Are in 2023
description: Most of them didn’t appear this year.
content: This is another end-of-the-year books list, but with a twist. These are the best books I read about 2023. They are, for the most part, voices from other years helping me make sense of our own. In a world where information keeps speeding up and thinning out, books slow time down, thickening the moment in which we live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: At Core of Purdue Pharma Case: Who Can Get Immunity in Settlements?
description: A broad ruling by the Supreme Court could mean the end of a strategy for resolving claims of mass injury in bankruptcy court in which organizations receive expansive legal protections.
content: For years, Purdue Pharma, the maker of the prescription painkiller OxyContin, had been entangled in lawsuits seeking to hold it to account for its role in the spiraling opioid crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: Big State Victories for Modi
description: Plus Israel’s campaign in Gaza.
content: Elections in northern Indian states were seen as a big test for Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Party, or B.J.P. Results showed that the party expanded its dominance in a key populous area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: The Climate Summit Embraces A.I., With Reservations
description: The idea of using artificial intelligence to fight emissions has made a splash at COP28, but there’s a catch: The energy it requires could make matters worse.
content: Artificial intelligence has been a breakout star in the opening days of COP28, the United Nations climate summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Entrepreneurs and researchers have dazzled attendees with predictions that the fast-improving technology could accelerate the world’s efforts to combat climate change and adapt to rising temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Eric Dyson
title: Beyoncé. Amen.
description: Her concert tour and her new film “Renaissance” show us what a more inclusive and loving church might look like.
content: The truth is plain, but elusive: Beyoncé Knowles-Carter is not only the world’s greatest entertainer, a feminist and a principled advocate of Black culture, but also something of a religious prophet. Her method is admittedly unorthodox and not uncontroversial: She delivers philosophy in Versace, theology in heels on a stage. Each night near the beginning of her performance on her Renaissance tour — and in the eponymous documentary film released on Friday — Beyoncé declared that she wanted the people gathered in her name to find a safe space for liberation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai, Alexandra Jacobs and Dwight Garner
title: The Critics’ Picks: A Year in Reading
description: The Book Review’s daily critics — Dwight Garner, Alexandra Jacobs and Jennifer Szalai — reflect on the books that stuck with them in 2023.
content: Since I review only nonfiction, I sometimes get tasked with writing about political memoirs — a number of which are geared toward getting you to believe what their politician-authors want you to believe, if not insisting that you should just shut your mind and let them do all the thinking for you. So it was with pleasure and relief that I encountered some philosophically-minded books this year. Amid all the hard sells and hot takes, these books provided some necessary counterprogramming. Their authors are more interested in opening up new ways of understanding than in telling people what to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Atmospheric Rivers to Bring Heavy Rain and Snow to Northwest U.S.
description: Three to seven inches of rain could drench parts of Washington and Oregon and more than a foot of snow could fall in areas of Idaho, Wyoming and Utah, forecasters said.
content: Back-to-back storms fueled by atmospheric rivers were expected to move over the northwestern United States this week, bringing heavy rains and snow and raising concerns about flooding, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Karoun Demirjian
title: U.S. Is Pressing Israel and Hamas to Resume Talks, White House Official Says
description: John Kirby said that Hamas was to blame for the breakdown in the negotiations, and that Israel was heeding U.S. advice on limiting civilian casualties.
content: The U.S. government is making an intense effort to persuade Israel and Hamas to resume negotiations so they can once again pause hostilities and exchange more prisoners for hostages, a White House spokesman said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lama Al-Arian
title: Over 60 Journalists Have Been Killed in the Israel-Gaza War. My Friend Was One.
description: To live through a nightmare and to witness others living through theirs are two very different things.
content: I was sitting in my apartment in Beirut on the evening of Oct. 13 when I read that journalists had been struck by a missile attack in southern Lebanon. My close friend, Issam Abdallah, was working in the area as a cameraman for Reuters to cover the border clashes between Israel and Hezbollah after the war in Gaza began just days earlier. I called him immediately. It was a ritual we had developed over the years: Whether we were on the front lines in Ukraine or Syria, each of us knew to expect a call from the other anytime a disaster struck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A Word’s History, Obscured by Snow and Lore
description: ‘American storms,’ Davy Crockett and a mysterious man called Lightning Ellis: The story behind the word ‘blizzard’ is no less opaque than the visibility during the storm itself.
content: Blizzards cause low visibility. And as it turns out, the history of the word “blizzard” is a bit blurry, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Broadway Babies, Singing Show Tunes for Seniors
description: What happened when four young theater actors performed for an older generation? “I was expecting to have the best show ever and that happened.”
content: “Oh, baby, give me one more chance,” sang Corey J, a former Little Michael in the Broadway musical “MJ.” Dressed in a black rimmed hat and a black turtleneck, jacket and pants, he slipped through the explosion of joy that is the chord progression of the Jackson 5 song “I Want You Back.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sharp Views on Dating and Marriage Today
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about why many women are not getting married.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Explosion at Catholic Mass in Philippines Kills at Least 4 and Injures Dozens
description: The blast, which was claimed by the Islamic State, occurred in a restive area in the south that was the site of a devastating battle with an ISIS affiliate six years ago.
content: At least four people were killed and dozens of others injured on Sunday in an explosion at a Roman Catholic Mass inside a university gymnasium in the southern Philippine city of Marawi, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Israeli Mothers Knew Their Sons Would Serve. But They Didn’t Expect War.
description: Many mothers are grappling with anxiety as their sons head off to fight in Gaza. “It felt like my children were being taken away, one by one, until no one was left,” one said.
content: The six mothers had gathered in a Jerusalem home on a recent Friday to prepare challah, the braided bread that Jews eat on the Sabbath. After they recited a blessing that is part of the ritual, each woman added a prayer of her own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Upheaval Continues at DeSantis Super PAC as Another Top Official Departs
description: The firing of the new chief executive creates more uncertainty at the well-funded group that has played a key role in the Florida governor’s effort to win the Republican primary.
content: The super PAC supporting Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida in his presidential campaign, which has seen a series of changes in the last month, went through another shake-up this week when it fired its new chief executive officer who had stepped in just nine days earlier, according to two people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Generation of Women Inspired by O’Connor, in Courtroom and Out
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, December 3, 2023.
content: “I had no role models, and then comes this woman, Sandra Day O’Connor, who says, ‘I can make decisions and I can think independently.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Geordie Walker, Guitarist for Killing Joke, Dies at 64
description: He helped define the look as well as the sound of the enduring British post-punk band, which influenced Nirvana, Metallica and others.
content: Geordie Walker, the founding guitarist of the British post-punk band Killing Joke, whose haunting, muscular riffs proved an inspiration to platinum-selling bands including Nirvana and Metallica, died on Sunday in Prague. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times
